history.content:
(a) In general for graduate programs, taking a lot of technical classes P/NP is not a good signal (one or two, with good reasons in mind, can work, but not 4-5), but talk to someone involved in 5th years Masters decisions to figure out how big an impact it will have. It is probably better to take some hits to your GPA than protect it via P/NPing tech classes, since grad schools will be able to see it in your transcript. 

(b) More than GPA, having done research under a prof who is willing to advise you for your 5th years is probably the biggest factor in admissions - GPA is definitely important, but you want to keep some time in your schedule for research work.

(c) Try out a math class first? Given the classes you're suggesting, it's likely you could double major in Math and CS, so trying out something like Math 104 is a good way to see if you like the material and want to do more of it.

As a graduating senior, I would advise you choose a small subset of classes to try out, and make sure you get a wide range of experiences here at Cal (research, clubs, internships, classes from different departments) instead of focusing on taking the maximum number of classes possible - if you go to grad school, you'll always have the chance to take more classes as and how you believe necessary :)

children.subject: Thank you so so much for such detailed answer!

history.content:
Hi! As a CS major interested in 5th year master program, I would like to ask is it wise to PNP upper div math courses? I will take all the hardcore cs core classes such as 170,189,162,ee126/127, etc. I want to take  math 110/104/113/185 because I want to learn these materials, but since they are not required by cs major, I want to put more time on cs courses, and don’t want math courses to potentially affect gpa.  
I would like to ask will it affect the application to 5th year master program? Is it true that I would be better off just not to take these math courses as pnp? But since I want to graduate earlier, the workload of CS courses is already intense. But I also want to learn those math knowledge as well..

Thanks!
history.subject: Is it wise to PNP math upper div courses as a CS major?
